attributes.comment:
Fees related to international adoption already create a barrier for infertile couples
to realize their goals of creating a family through this form of adoption. Increased
fees will not encourage more families to use our flawed domestic adoption
system. It will only hurt these US victims of reproductive diseases and the
orphaned victims of poverty/disease abroad. The agencies that process the
paperwork for international adoptions already leave the putrid taste of bureaucracy
in the mouths of hopeful couples. They force adoption and referral delays and
work-related absences in the process. They cost the couples hundreds of dollars
and weeks of time for a small determination and sheet of paper. To add to that?
is abuse. Sit in an office with a woman while a nurse schedules her fifth D&C;
hold a woman?s hand when the doctor?s tell her that her last IVF cycle failed and
she had spent $60,000 and taken out loans but still won?t have a child; go to a
domestic adoption counselor and hear about the fees and likelihood a couple will
be able to adopt a healthy infant from this country; watch your wife?s face when
her siblings and closest friends announce their pregnancies and feel the shame of
impotence; listen to the shattering quiet the day your wife gets her period each
month; and don?t be bitter when you find out that the government that won?t
declare infertility a disease that should be covered by insurance will raise the
costs associated with international adoption. The government that gives women
the freedom to murder fetuses, allows abusive parents visitation rights to their
victims, and rewards parenthood with tax breaks and credits, is now adding to
their barriers?taking back part of the adoption credit--that was your last hope for
starting a family. Pardon me for not being polite and gracious.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Sidney Porter
